In allowing student college debt to be forgiven, it is argued that this may set a negative trend for these young adults. With this college debt being forgiven may come the notion that futures debts that are not related to school may also be payed off by someone other than the current student themself. While this may have more serious consequences in their futures, in the short term it may also influence students to further establish more college loan debt. I do not agree with these insinuations because the students that would be recieving this help will not be so jaded as to expect further help. They have already maintained a healthy GPA and show a dedication to their future in planning to continue their education into college. These are not the type of people that would be content to keep their education going by living off handouts, there for they would not fall into this false sense of security that the opposition assumes will accompany this debt forgiveness program. Because these students would be saving so much money by way of this program, the question of what they will be spending their savings on is posed. The opposition to this program argues that this money will be spent on what some would consider to be "frivolous items", but with these students I doubt that this would be the case. In attending college they have made it clear that they would like to be productive members of society, and economic stability is a part of that. Those who would benefit from this program would not be likely to pour their savings into frivolity, but would rather be too consumed with their studies to engage in this behavior. In this day and age of baby boomers criticizing the younger generations for their dependence on hand outs, the "tax payer" perspective plays a large role in our nations political arena. Those who abide by this way of thinking that all tax payer money they give will automatically go towards things that they do not support, argue that the one trillion dollars that taxpayers have already put into these programs is enough and that the students and their families should be paying their own way for the aforementioned students' education. This however, is easier said than done. Many families cannot afford the massive amount of college debt to befall them should one or all of their children were to attend college. The students themselves also cannot pay off this debt alone hence the need for this program. Those in society who do not support tax payer assistance of other's college education have forgotten that the key to a successful and competitive nation today in our world is the education of our youth. While the opposition is large, this program should occur so as to help both the students prosper as well as our nation.

Giving currently enrolled students with high grade-point averages amnesty for college loans will undoubtedly have undesirable consequences. Firstly, if the nation eliminates these debts now, it insinuates to future college applicants that the same policy will be in place in later years, setting an unfair precedent that may be impossible to maintain. Furthermore, if students are provided with the money that they would have spent on tuition, and are told that they may use it in any way that suits them, the money will likely be spent carelessly on materialistic and unimportant items, degrading the youth's perception of the value and importance of money. Also, roughly $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion dollars in student debt is being paid for on a federal level, with American taxpayer's dollars. Such a hefty financial burden should not be placed on US society as a whole, but rather the people to whom it belongs. Providing today's youth with the mentality that their debts can be wiped clean will not instill in them the drive or desire to work hard; it will encourage laziness and prevent many young people from appreciating the education they are being provided with, regardless of their financial situation.

Although there are many benefits to enforcing the use of the amnesty program in the US, there are many potential problems that can result from its enforcement. One specific consequence of this amnesty is how it will set a precedent for similar loans in the future. The student may believe that future loans will be forgiven, and, therefore, will accumulate additional college debt. This means that students following this precedent will believe that they accumulate large debts and take more expensive items without fear. A second unintended result of this amnesty is that some students may choose to spend their money on unnecessary items instead of on tuition. They will be extending their loans for something not related to their education even though the purpose of granting amnesty is to allow the students additional educational opportunities. Statistics show that in the last 30 years, the cost of a four-year college tuition has grown rapidly by about 357 percent. By these results, the introduction of the student amnesty program will set a new trend. That is, students will get debt amnesty and will not have to pay for college loans. By introducing the new program, the college will need to beware of the various consequences that may occur.

On the one hand, forgiving student loans will enable students to have some sort of economic security after graduating. However, this will set a precedent for future loans, which would accumulate more college debt. Others argue that if loan debts are forgiven, some students may take this as a free pass and spend money on frivolous items rather than on tuition. Furthermore, US taxpayers would be paying for their education because about $1 trillion of the current $1.2 trillion in student debt is in federal student loans. However, in the last 30 years, the cost of college tuition has grown by 357%, meaning that students add more debt to pay for a college education, which is just setting a continuing trend for every generation after. College needs to be made affordable, but not at the cost of the students or the taxpayers.

However, there are opponents to this debt amnesty program, and there are several factors that contribute to their opposition. For instance, if current students are forgiven their debt, they will expect to be given similar loans later on, which just means more debt accumulated. Secondly, the money that is not being spent on paying off loans will be spent of unnecessary items rather than tuition. Also, since 5/6ths of student debt is federal loans, this means that regular US taxpayers are paying for a student's debt rather than the student and their family. Lastly, the cost of a 4-year public college education has grown by 357% in the last 30 years, meaning that more and more debt will be stacked on as students enroll in college which creates a continuing trend of increasing debt.

Some would argue that this policy of debt forgiveness will have more negative effects than positive ones. In the last three decades alone, the price of college tuition has grown exponentially. It has grown by 357 percent on average. In addition to this, any student who meets the requirements will likely spend more money than they would if they had to pay it back. Many of these loans are federal, meaning that it is the taxpayers who will suffer the most from the debt amnesty program.
